tn.text: This is the name of a people group from Tishbe. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a town in the region of Gilead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: As Yahweh, the God of Israel lives
tn.text: This phrase is an oath to emphasize that what he will say is true.
This is an idiom that means "to serve." AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
drops of water that form on the plants during the night
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is the name of a very small stream. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This phrase is used to introduce how Yahweh will take care of Elijah during the drought. AT: "There"
large, black birds (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: as the word of Yahweh commanded
tn.text: Here "the word" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "as Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a very small stream. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:17:02|17:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"in that area" or "in that country"
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "him" refers to Elijah.
This is a town. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The word "Look" here adds emphasis to what follows.
This phrase is an oath to emphasize that what she will say is true.
"only a little bit of meal"
"flour." This what is used to make bread.
The word "See" here adds emphasis to what follows.
This may refer to two sticks or to only a few sticks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: that we may eat it, and die
tn.text: It is implied that they will die because they do not have anymore food. AT: "that we may eat. Afterwards, we will starve to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: afterward make some for you and for your son
tn.text: It is implicit that there would be enough flour and oil to make more bread. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is an idiom that means Yahweh causes it to rain. AT: "Yahweh causes rain to fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: She and Elijah, along with her household, ate for many days
tn.text: In the original language it says, "And she and he and her household ate for many days." It is unclear who "he" is. Possible meanings are 1) Elijah, the widow, and her son ate for many days or 2) the widow, her son, and everyone living in her house ate for many days or 3) Elijah, the widow, and everyone living in her house ate for many days.

Possible meanings for "household" are 1) this refers only to the widow's son or 2) this refers to other people who live in her house but are not named in the story or 3) this refers to her son and others living in her house.

tn.ref: just as the word of Yahweh had said
tn.text: Here "word" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "just as Yahweh had said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the woman's son, the woman who owned the house
tn.text: "the son of the woman who owned the house"

tn.ref: there was no more breath left in him
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying the boy died. AT: "he stopped breathing" or "he died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The phrase "man of God" is another title for a prophet.
This means sins in general not a specific sin. AT: "of my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])
Here "he" refers to Elijah.
Here "his" refers to Elijah.

tn.ref: have you also brought disaster on the widow with whom I am staying, by killing her son?
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Elijah is truly asking a question. AT: "why would you cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" or 2) Elijah uses a question to express how sad he is. AT: "surely, you would not cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: have you also brought disaster on the widow
tn.text: Causing the widow to suffer is spoken of as if "disaster" were an object that is placed on the widow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "also" means in addition to the disaster that the drought has caused.
This is an idiom. AT: "lay on top of the child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Yahweh listened to the voice of Elijah
tn.text: Here "voice" represents what Elijah prayed. AT: "Yahweh answered Elijah's prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the life of the child returned to him, and he revived
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. AT: "the child came back to life" or "the child lived again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "his" refers to Elijah.
The word "See" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh in your mouth is true
tn.text: Here "word" represents a message. Also, "mouth" represents what Elijah said. AT: "the message that you spoke from Yahweh is true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
